title: Friday, 4th November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

.. with our shared love of numbers going up and down.

BE

Who's ready for today's numbers-going-up-and-down fun?

11:02 am
BE

Yeah! Numbers!

BE

But first, tradition dictates a portrait.

BE

11:03 am
BE

SCM Private co-founder Gina Miller, of course. As pictured on the front of the Times.

BE

Or, if you prefer, on the front of The Sun.

BE

11:04 am
BE

(Note to Sun: Adobe Gamma helps to correctly calibrate your Photoshop RGB balance.)

BE

(Otherwise you might inadvertently end up looking like massive racists.)

undefined
11:05 am
BE

(@Boncoeur: for as long as I need to pay a mortgage, I bloody love my job.)

BE

(@Otter: dunno, Not looked into it. Not entirely sure why it's important.)

BE

Numbers, then. They're down, mostly.

11:06 am
BE

FTSE off 1.3% at pixel, 6703.

BE

Partly following the US overnight, which has its own problems.

BE

Sterling steady-ish at $1.246 so we can't blame that for once.

11:09 am
BE

Heading into movers, we have Hikma getting smashed.

Hikma Pharmaceuticals PLC (HIK:LSE): Last: 1,643, down 102 (-5.85%), High: 1,711, Low: 1,575, Volume: 1.21m
BE

Post this Bloomberg story overnight

11:09 am
BE

http://www.bloombe...-filed-by-year-end

BE

U.S. prosecutors are bearing down on generic pharmaceutical companies in a sweeping criminal investigation into suspected price collusion, a fresh challenge for an industry that’s already reeling from public outrage over the spiraling costs of some medicines.
The antitrust investigation by the Justice Department, begun about two years ago, now spans more than a dozen companies and about two dozen drugs, according to people familiar with the matter. The grand jury probe is examining whether some executives agreed with one another to raise prices, and the first charges could emerge by the end of the year, they said.

BE

Hikma's not mentioned specifically

11:11 am
BE

...... but it's #6 in US generics and does make several of the drugs mentioned.

BE

Also note that price inflation's quite a big part of the Hikma story ....

BE

Post the Roxane acquisition, which seems to have put it straight into the political firing line.

11:12 am
BE

Here's Citi.

BE

Hikma’s US generics division current represents 30% of group sales and 10% of EBIT. The company is looking to commercialise the Roxane pipeline over the coming years to drive EBIT margin expansion from 5% to greater than 30%.

BE

Citi also highlights the Egyptian pound's devaluation, and that 6% of Hikma's sales are in Egypt.

11:13 am
BE

CMD preview incoming.

BE

We expect Hikma to focus on the growth opportunities for its Branded, Injectables and US Generics divisions. Granularity on the Roxane pipeline is unlikely though we wonder whether the company will attempt to improve confidence by providing floor guidance for US generics excluding any contribution from generic Advair. FDA action on Mylan’s and Hikma/Roxane’s ANDAs are slated for Mar-17 and May-17 respectively, with Teva and Sandoz the next expected filers. The importance of generic Advair for consensus expectations at Hikma is significant, especially given the diminished Roxane pipeline outlook given recent developments for generic versions of Xeloda (pricing point post approval significantly lower than expectations), Xyrem (patent estate stronger than expected) and Fanapt (court decision found Roxane to infringe).

BE

....... That's ahead of the CMD on November 5th.

11:14 am
BE

Hikma has acknowledged that Roxane FY17 revenue guidance of $700-750m will be difficult to achieve if Advair is materially delayed. Given expectations for a 2H17 launch this, in our view, implies management expects 2017 sales of $75-100m (15-20% share assuming 50% discount to brand) and we assume $200-250m in 2018 (for reference our Vectura model assumes $490m of generic Advair sales). Hikma has yet to comment on its capacity to serve the market. Running a scenario where Advair is removed from our forecasts, at an 80% contribution margin (15% royalty to Vectura 15%, COGS and 35% tax rate), implies a 4-8% and 25-30% hit to 2017/18e group EPS.

BE

They remain neutral, mostly because you could drive a bus through the valuation spread.

BE

We like the LT fundamentals given management’s track record of value creation, structural growth opportunities for Branded/Injectable Generics, and the optionality provided by a strong balance sheet. That said the political rhetoric around US generic drug price increases and current sentiment around Hikma’s ability to successfully commercialise the Roxane pipeline (84 assets) will, in our view, keep the shares rangebound. We forecast a 2017-22e sales/EPS CAGR of 9%/17%. Our £21 PE valuation is based on a 20x 2017E PE, and our NPV valuation is £26 (WACC 8%, g=1%) with a bull-bear of £38-15.

11:16 am
BE

The drugs mentioned by Bloomberg that Hikma makes, by the way, are digoxin and doxycycline.

BE

They're very small in terms of group revenue. 1-2%.

BE

But you'll remember the fun we had with doxycycline in 2014.

11:18 am
BE

As in, it used to cost sub $5 a dose. Then it cost more than $100,

BE

Shortages of the drug have benefited Hikma Pharmaceuticals, one of three suppliers that control more than 90 per cent of the market. Hikma raised sales guidance three times last year after halting production of the medicine, then starting again once supply had been squeezed and prices had soared.

BE

https://www.ft.com...-a0c0-00144feabdc0

11:19 am
BE

............. Which might go some way to explaining the regulatory interest.

undefined
BE

Think we might go Brexit free on this side of the page today. The ROTR has opinions, and I'd feel it somewhat rude to interrupt them.

11:21 am
BE

Instead, sofas.

DFS Furniture PLC (DFS:LSE): Last: 232.10, down 31.6 (-11.98%), High: 237.00, Low: 225.60, Volume: 3.02m
BE

Advent slots half its remaining stake ...... at 240p!

11:22 am
BE

Suggestions we had (and I think wrote in the paper overnight) were that Advent fancied a rather higher price

BE

But no. They've ended up slotting below the 255p float price

BE

Question:

11:23 am
BE

Has Advent made any proper money on DFS?

BE

It bought the business in 2010 for about £500m.

BE

Several refinancings followed, most notably the 2013 one that funded a bung to "shareholders" (ie. Advent)

11:24 am
BE

Then Advent floated again in 2015 at a valuation of ...... about £500m.

BE

Its secondary sales since have been on a valuation of ........ about £500m.

BE

So you're looking at the 2013 refi bung as the only real cash Advent took out.

11:25 am
BE

It hardly seems worth all that bother.

undefined
BE

Let me find some sellside to brighten the mood.

11:01 am
BE

FT Alphaville's attempt to unite an increasingly polarised and fractious British public ...

BE

Two reasons, as far as I could work out ............

BE

First, contract renewal talks in Argentina

11:30 am
BE

Rolling over deals that were signed in happier times

BE

Think management's already guided towards a 30% hit there, but even that looks ambitious now.

BE

Second, Karpowership!

11:31 am
BE

Turkish shipbuilder. Part of Karadeniz.

BE

It makes floating power stations.

BE

11:32 am
BE

And it's making a lot of them. Big expansion.

BE

Which means Aggreko's EM business faces a rather interesting new competitor.

BE

Anyway, Morgan Stanley says that with Aggreko at a seven-year low it's all probably in the price now.

11:33 am
BE

We retain our concerns over long-term pressures on the IPP
business model. However, we upgrade as the shares now trade
almost 2 standard deviations below mid-cycle multiples, 2017
consensus estimates look supported, and we see signs that
underlying trading and returns should improve in 2017

BE

Reason one:

BE

Valuation low enough to be reasonable: Aggreko now trades at consensus
N12m / MSe P/E of 10.7/10.4x and EV/EBITA of 8.8/8.6x, approaching 2
standard deviations below its mid-cycle average since 2004

11:34 am
BE

Reason two:

BE

2017e consensus looks supported: A trading profit bridge for 2017e
suggests consensus of £279m should be supported. It also now implies
that consensus has already factored in a full reprice of Aggreko's 450MW
in Argentina. Other factors in our trading profit bridge are: £16m from
incremental IPP contract wins relative to churn; Venezuela impacting
profits by £7m (£2m trading and a £5m further impairment to receivables);
and N. America grows 5% (as upstream O&G recovers) adding £6m. Cost
savings add £37m and FX £22m.

BE

Reason three:

11:34 am
BE

Signs of improved underlying trading in 2017: If the relationship between
Wartsila Energy Solutions and IPP orders holds, it suggests IPP orders can
continue to improve from current levels, with 2015 as the trough in IPP
orders. Also, Aggreko N. American revenue growth has tracked the N.
American oil rig count since 2004, and the latter inflected in 2016.

BE

Reason four:

BE

Returns should improve in 2017: ROIC fell from 18.4% in 2010 to 8.8% in
2016, and has been a leading indicator for the stock as investors caught up
with the implications of lower margins in IPP. Margin gains from cost cuts
and lower growth in the capital base mean we model 2017 ROIC of 9.5%.

11:35 am
BE

The one footnote I'd add to all that is that Aggreko's balance sheet looks bulletproof no matter how bad things get.

undefined
BE

(@xchaotic: I'm trying to find the ML session we did on the day of the GoPro float ...)

11:40 am
BE

(... but the FT.com search function is still very much a work in progress. Suffice to say, we weren't terribly keen.)

BE

What else, then?

BE

There's Lloyds, which is getting a shove from JPM.

11:41 am
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 55.49, down 0.54 (-0.96%), High: 56.63, Low: 55.30, Volume: 66.52m
BE

As part of a sector review, which I'll quote sparingly for easons.

BE

Although UK banks are materially higher from the lows following the
referendum, Lloyds has lagged UK/EU banks: -14%/-19% relative to
SX7P/FABANK from 24th June. Recent Q3’16 results were disappointing
with a P&L miss and capital build was driven by a one-off gilt reclassification
in our view. However, we believe DPS prospects are positive as the group‘s
CT1 generation is well above other UK banks alongside the largest buffer
going into the 2016 stress test, results due 30th Nov. If, as we expect, Lloyds
performs better than peers, we would expect market focus to shift towards the
potential for special divs. If the capital return above 13% guidance is taken
literally, FY’16 DPS including special could be as high as 4.7p (vs JPMe 3p).
We are not changing our cautious view on UK banks in the sector context, but
see Lloyds (and Virgin Money) as relatively attractive at current levels against
our UW view on RBS, CYBG and Metro Bank.

11:43 am
BE

So the BOE's neutral bias doesn't really matter much ......

BE

........ softer Brexit might, but that's not something to bet on.

BE

What you can bet on is that banks will probably be able to defend NIM better than investors assume, says JPM

11:44 am
BE

And Lloyds will look good in the stress tests.

BE

We don’t expect any UK bank
to fall below the hurdle rate in 2016 stress tests, but we would not be
surprised to see all UK banks coming close to their SRPs. We think Lloyds
with 8.1% CT1 or £18.2bn buffer to the SRP and hurdle rate is best
positioned relative to the 5.1% drawdown in the 2014 test

BE

Most interesting, I guess, is the Lloyds divi projection.

11:46 am
BE

3.0p, 3.5p and 4p for 2016, 17 and 18 respectively.

BE

(Specials plus normals.)

undefined
11:50 am
BE

............. and into results.

BE

(That rather long pause was me trying to find something other than results to talk about, and failing.)

Paddy Power Betfair PLC (PPB:LSE): Last: 8,909, up 328.6 (+3.83%), High: 8,930, Low: 8,805, Volume: 180.56k
11:51 am
BE

Q3 beat, guidance raised.

BE

EBITDA growth of 53%!

BE

On sales up 25%, or 15% at constant currency.

11:52 am
BE

Merger synergies running slightly ahead.

BE

"And so what we believe will be an extended upgrade cycle begins," says Davy.

BE

Numbers are "not too shabby during a year in which on-going integration work could justifiably have been expected to act as a distraction from day-to-day execution."

11:53 am
BE

We have spent much of this year emphasising the operating
leverage potential of this newly merged company only to find
that this potential was being overshadowed by a combination
of adverse regulatory changes in Australia, an admittedly
disappointing H1 earnings outcome in Australia and the general
sell-off in the sector driven by regulatory concerns in the UK.
The fact of the matter is that our top of the range forecasts
already build in substantial buffers for adverse regulatory and
tax changes while underestimating the scope for future profit
margin expansion. That applies even more so to consensus, in
our view.

BE

Goldman's thoughts are more Goldman .....

BE

A relatively strong statement with 9M16 underlying EBITDA of £294mn, up
£82mn yoy proforma vs. company-compiled consensus +£84mn for 2016,
while management’s 2016 proforma EBITDA guidance increased to £390-
£405mn, 3% above consensus at the midpoint (ex. £5m early synergy
delivery in 2016) and 5% above previous guidance (ex. early synergy
delivery). 3Q16 net revenue growth decelerated to 15% (ex FX) from 20% in
2Q16, albeit in the context of 3Q16 marketing spend +14% yoy underlying
(1H16: +31%) and slightly less benefit from the Euro. On outlook,
management says industry competition is high as is regulatory uncertainty,
but believes its scale and capability position it well for profitable growth.

11:55 am
BE

They're neutral.

BE

PPB trades at a CY17E P/E of 22x and a 5.1% FCF yield, which adequately
reflects its growth prospects (CY16-19E EPS CAGR 21%) and high return on
capital (CY17E CROCI 37%), in our view. Our 12-month price target of
9,800p is based on EV/EBIT vs. 1-yr forward EBIT growth for online
consumer discretionary peers at CY20E, discounted back to CY17 (at 9%
pa).

undefined
11:57 am
BE

(@DRichi: no thoughts whatsoever. I genuinely have never given the Egyptian pound peg even a moment's thought.)

BE

And so we drift to a standstill.

BE

And since it's midday, pretty much, let's close.

12:00 pm
BE

(@Paper Chase: true, though it's been reasonably eventful between those two points.)

BE

Thanks for your comments, both today and this week.

BE

Paul's back on Monday, in theory.

12:01 pm
BE

See you then. Afternoon all.

BE

Aggreko, for instance, which has been an absolutely awful market of late.
